Thomas,

It is currently not possible to specify a function for the rate at=
 
which a wall moves from Matlab, but you can do it from Python.  If you 
w=
ant to run your simulation in Python, all you need to do is this:

1) Creat=
e 2 reactors that share a common wall (A), and make it flexible 
enough to =
maintain pressure equilibrium.
2) Add a second wall (B) to reactor 2 with a=
 specified vdot rate vs. 
time.  This will actually change the total volume=
, not just volume 2, 
with time, since the rate of volume change for each r=
eactor is computed 
by summing over all of its walls. Thus, the rate of cha=
nge of volume of 
reactor 1 plus reactor 2 equals the specified vdot for wa=
ll B:  dV/dt_1 
+ dV/dt_2 =3D vdot(A) + (vdot(B) - vdot(A)) =3D vdot(B).

T=
he only reason this can't be done from Matlab too is that I haven't 
gotten=
 around to adding the necessary interfacing code to the Matlab 
toolbox. It=
's not hard to do, and I'll add it to the list of requested 
enhancements.
=

Dave Goodwin



On Feb 18, 2004, at 7:37 AM, thomassteinhilber wrote:

> D=
ear Mr. Goodwin,
>
> I=B4m a PhD student at the Technical University of Mun=
ich and using
> Cantera for the simulation of gas compression up to auto-ig=
nition.
> With little changes to your matlab demo "ignite2" I managed the
>=
 compression of one gas-volume (wich was actually quite easy, thanks
> for =
the good demo versions!).
>
> Now I would like to compress two, coupled rea=
ctors, with pressure
> equilibrium. Input is the volume change of the total=
 volume (Volume
> (Reactor1)+Volume(Reactor2)). In your Python-description =
"Zero-
> Dimensional Kinetics" I found the command
>
> vrate=3DPolynomial([=
5.0, -1.0, 10.0])
> wall1.set(Vdot=3Dvrate)
>
> Is this command also availa=
ble for Matlab, or do you have a better
> idea to compress two volumina wit=
h a given volume change?
>
> Thank you,
> Thomas Steinhilber
